title_sort: william e. vandemark to walt whitman, 16 december 1863
title: William E. Vandemark to Walt Whitman, 16 December 1863
text: Dear brother and comrad[comrade]I received a letter from yo[you] this mornin[morning] dated the 13 and was very glad to hear from yo[you] i[I] am not very well i[I] have good dele[deal] of pain in my hip and head i[I] see by the tones of yiour[your] letter that yo[you] are not very well i[I] hope by the time this letter reaches yo[you] they may find yo[you] well i[I] know it is bad to loos a brother but the lord giveth and the lord taketh away an then we must all sooner or later give up this worldâ€” i[I] had a few lines from home this morning my little girl is sick and i[I] feeling bad to think that i[I] cant[can't] see her now but my prays is that she may better soon well father i[I] am going to my ridgement[regiment] i[I] think the doctor marked so but i[I] cant[can't] march we expect evry[every] day to start for elickazandry[Alexandria] [Alexandria] to the convalesent[convalescent] camp if i[I] could get to the city i[I] could get my discharge but i[I] cant[can't] father i[I] thank yo[you] for seeing about my discriptave[descriptive] list for they owe me now six months pay and i[I] want i[I] very bad they paid all those that had thair[their] discriptave[descriptive] lists the doctors here are meen[men] for they have no feeing to a man father the wether[whether] is getting cold here now and i[I] will be glad wen i[I] get away from here i[I] long to see yo[you] and have a good talk with yo[you] for yo[you] have ben[been] kind to me wen i[I] Could not help my self and i[I] hope the day may come wen i[I] can do for yo[you] some good in return for father you donte[don't] know how i[I] do love you i[I] donte[don't] know wy[why] it is i[I] am more attached yo[you] than enny[any] one that i[I] was acquainted with the papers gives us good news now conserning[concerning] the war i[I] hope theat[that] peace may soone[soon] be proclaimed thair[their] has been a grate many lives lost in the cruel war father i[I] wish that yo[you] would send yiour likenes and i[I] will send yo[you] mine & i[I] wish that i[I] could see yo[you] i[I] hope that i[I] may soon see yo[you] their is about 15 rebs here now they get all they want and the docters[doctors] pays thair[their] attention to the will the rebs over our men like dogs now strange it is well it may be all for the best i[I] hope they will turn thair[their] corse[course] before it is to lateDear father and Comrad[Comrade] i[I] will close now good by and may god take care of yo[you] and that we may soon meet from friend & son William Vandemark to his comrad[comrade] and father and friend William E. Vandemark to Walt Whitman, 16 December 1863
